page.title: 04THE CARLISLE CANAL
page.content: Before the railways were built and when the roads were in a shocking state,Carlisle needed ports to keep it supplied with goods from other parts of Britain and abroad.The old ports for Carlisle were at Rockcliff,Sands- field and Bowness.Mostly,the cargo was coal from West Cumberland and wheat. The business people of Carlisle de- cided to build a canal.This canal would bring ships right into Carlisle. It was opened on March 12th 1823,and cost nearly Â£90,000.It stretched for 11 miles,from Fisher's Cross<renamed Port Carlisle>through Burgh to the canal basin in Carlisle<behind United Biscuits' factory>.Coal,timber,bricks, cotton and paper were imported for Carlisle's factories,while passengers could catch a boat to Liverpool from Port Carlisle.However,the canal closed on August 1st 1854.
